summary: <n> background. cardiovascular disease ( cvd ) is the leading cause of death in the western world. <n> aspirin reduces the risk of cvd. <n> aim. to compare the benefit of aspirin with placebo in patients with cvd <n>. <n> methods. a randomised controlled trial ( rct ) of aspirin in patients with cvd ( aspirin for cardiovascular disease [ acvd ] trial ). <n> <n> results. <n> the trial included 336 women ( median age 60 years ). statin therapy reduces cardiovascular disease ( cvd ) risk in patients with type 2 diabetes, but its impact on mortality is unknown. <n> we conducted a randomized controlled trial of statin therapy in patients with type 2 diabetes to determine whether statin therapy reduces cvd mortality. <n> statin users had higher cvd mortality than non - users ( hazard ratio 0.90 [ 95% confidence interval 0.741.14 ] ). <n> however, the relative risk of death was lower in statin users than in non - users ( 0.63 [ 0.59 a recent meta - analysis of randomized controlled trials ( rcts ) of aspirin compared with nonaspirin aspirin showed that the benefit of aspirin compared with nonaspirin aspirin was greater in men than in women. <n> this finding has important implications for the use of aspirin in the primary prevention of cardiovascular disease ( cvd ). <n> primary prevention of cvd is defined as the use of low - dose aspirin to prevent cvd events in the general population.

background : liver dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis ( lafs ) is the most common chronic liver disease worldwide with incidence particularly among individuals with type 2 diabetes. <n> peptide-1s have emerged as effective weight loss agents with potential benefits in lafs. <n> aim : study aimed to evaluate safety and efficacy of improving histologic features of lafs.methods:in this meta-analysis, randomized controlled trials evaluating effect of approved biopsy-1s in patients with lafs were included. <n> primary outcomes were resolution without liver fibrosis is the most common cause of chronic liver disease. <n> the disease is characterized by the accumulation of fatty tissue in the liver parenchyma. <n> liver fibrosis is usually self - limiting, but can progress to cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma ( hcc ). <n> hcc is the most common cause of end - stage liver disease. <n> liver transplantation is the only effective treatment for patients with advanced liver fibrosis. <n> however, hcc is often resistant to liver transplantation, leading to relapse of the disease.

diabetes mellitus ( yet2 ) is a systemic metabolic disorder increasingly implicated in central nervous system ( cns ) dysfunction. <n> this study evaluated region-specific alterations in dopaminergic neurotransmission within the hippocampus and their association with social behavioral deficits in diabetic mice. <n> two groups were designated as control group and diabetic group. <n> control group was designated as group 1, and control group was designated as group 2. <n> diabetes was caused by injecting 50 mg/kg of streptozotocin for five consecutive days to induce diabetes. after inducing type 2 diabetes mellitus ( t2 dm ) is associated with cognitive decline and neurobehavioral dysfunction. <n> we recently reported that t2 dm induces dysregulation of dopaminergic signaling in the hippocampus and prefrontal cortex ( pfc ), which contributes to cognitive decline and neurobehavioral dysfunction in t2 dm mice. here <n>, we discuss the implications of our findings. key clinical messagediabetes mellitus is associated with a wide range of neurobehavioral dysfunctions, including cognitive, motor, sensory, and emotional dysregulation. <n> these dysfunctions contribute to poor quality of life, increased cardiovascular risk, and increased morbidity and mortality. <n> further studies are needed to better understand the role of neurobehavioral dysfunction in the development and progression of diabetes, to identify potential therapeutic targets for mitigating diabetes - associated neurobehavioral dysfunction, and to assess the impact of neurobehavioral dysfunction on quality of life.

influenza infection is a well - established trigger of respiratory cardiovascular complications in older adults and is associated with substantial clinical and socioeconomic burden, particularly in high - risk individuals and in those with underlying cardiovascular disease. <n> influenza vaccination is a powerful preventive tool with benefits in reducing major adverse cardiovascular events and in reducing established cardioprotective therapies. evidence linking influenza vaccination to significant reductions in cardiovascular morbidity and mortality is growing. <n> the effectiveness of influenza vaccination in protecting against cardiovascular disease is supported by meta-analyses and randomized controlled trials. <n> evidence linking influenza vaccination to better outcomes in other chronic conditions is emerging. <n> national and international recommendations to optimize influenza vaccination are being implemented in many countries.
